body: Yes, that does sound better.

@Parth-Brahmbhatt with the new consumer api one can subscribe to multiple topics so we need to keep the group around.

nit: Please fix the PR name to include the issue description. Will make it easier for us to merge :)
@chamberlain1990 please close this pull request.
LGTM. Had some minor comments
@gwenshap thanks for the feedback....if it is a known flaky test then we should be good I think.

@gwenshap Adding an `implements` and thereby introducing an additional interface into the type hierarchy should be a binary compatible change, so I can't see any issues.

I would ask whether there are any other classes that we should consider doing this to as well. Off the top of my head I can't think of anything else but I feel like it should be surprising if that's the only POJO in o.a.k.common that might need to be serialized...

good point @ewencp on "if TopicPartition class alone should be marked for serialization". I was looking into the Kafka consumer interface doc for its different method signatures and I see that User could also pass a reference to OffsetAndMetadata (org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer package)....which means to say if he/she wants to serialize app object that uses OffsetMetadata then this class also needs to be serialized.

I have made the needed change and same is update in the PR.

Was looking at the Producer class too (which the app will use) and don't see any usage of Kafka class that would need serialization to recover back from checkpoint.

I have made the above inference based on possible classes that could be used by a application and would need a way to recover back after a checkpoint (a more usual case in case of Kafka consumer only).

your thoughts?

Thanks

Praveen

One thing to think about is what is our serialization compatibility policy. It's a bit of a pain to maintain serializability compatibility and from looking at our codebase, we don't normally make our classes Serializable.

true @ijuma it can be pain to maintain if used for every classes and especially in inheritance hierarchy. 

Given that Kafka allows the feature of being able to go back to a needed offset or start at needed offset, it is necessary that consumer app has info of the offsets at respective partition for respective topic.

There are 2 choices for the app, either regularly checkpoint the offset info for the topic/partition in a data-structure of its own (forcing to create these TopicPartition objects from this data-structure when  needed) or reuse Kafka's classes (hence be able to reuse). 

In Kafka client case given that TopicPartition and OffsetAndMetadata are classes for storing this metadata needed for operation we should make them serializable.

Earlier (before 0.9) one could use the class TopicAndPartition which was a case class and by default it was serializable. We could use that with 0.9 too but it makes clients depend on the kafka (core/server) jar which can make it bulky for an app whose need is just for kafka-clients and also we will still need to do the conversions to TopicPartition when needed to call respective consumer method.

@gwenshap I think it makes sense except I'm not sure that we'll find out about any conflicts before another release -- we only have a few connectors that we know will be tested against the trunk version of Connect with the new dependency....
@ijuma @praveend Maybe we can add a unit test to force serialization compatibility if we're going to mark the classes as Serializable?
@gwenshap : Sure, I updated the description to include more details. Is this ok?
@fpj can you take a look one more time when you get a chance?

@praveend Understood about clients needing a mechanism to serialize and deserialize such classes. Java Serialization is just one such mechanism, however, there are several others. Personally, I think Java Serialization is not a good mechanism for a number of reasons (compatibility, performance, security, etc.), but I understand that it's very convenient (in the short-term, at least, people often regret using it later). The fact that TopicAndPartition was Serializable was kind of accidental (one sadly gets that automatically when using case classes).

If we do decide to support Java Serialization in some of our classes, we should do that with a good understanding of what it means if we need to change them in the future. And we certainly should include test(s) as @ewencp is suggesting.
Quick heads-up @Parth-Brahmbhatt, @fpj is away until the new year.

Full build passed (one spurious failure) from a branch that includes the fix I mentioned above. Once this is merged to @fpj's PR we should be good to go. 
https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_systest_branch_builder2/26/
@ijuma  @fpj  @Parth-Brahmbhatt I see the comments from @fpj addressed any reason for this PR to wait further.

@MayureshGharat I think what Gwen meant was to update the PR title which now reads as KAFKA-1860 to that of full JIRA title "KAFKA-1860 File system errors are not detected unless Kafka tries to write"
@sasakitoa How about an update to the corresponding unit tests in `o.a.k.common.utils.UtilsTest`? Should just be a matter of adding one more example that uses capitals.

@benstopford @fpj This looks good to merge aside from the comment I left about the `use_authorizer` parameter to `KafkaService`. We only have one `Authorizer` implementation, so the parameter kind of makes sense in the scope of only Kafka's tests, but we should think of the `Service` classes as semi-public interfaces we want to be careful about changing -- they should be reusable by others to write system tests. If anyone wanted to test other authorizer implementations, I think the current `use_authorizer` parameters wouldn't be a great solution -- they'd have to add still another option (or make assumptions about the implementation by setting the `authorizer_class_name` field on `KafkaService` directly).

@ewencp @ijuma sure.....Any handy pointers on how the tests are structured...I will put in the needed test case that will try serializing the TopicParition and OffsetAndMetadata class object (expecting no exception) and then de-serialize it back and check for equality.

@ewencp Thank you for advice.
I added unit tests for capitals.
@ewencp Rebased and updated based on comments

@lindong28 Without the deepCopy(), I'm seeing the test case fail.

Merged to trunk and 0.9.0.

@ZoneMayor Can you explain how this patch should fix the underlying problem reported in KAFKA-2944? It looks like it refactors some code, but I don't understand how it will avoid the NullPointerException?

The bug is definitely transient -- it's timing dependent because it occurs only when shutdown (and therefore `stop()` calls) occur at just the right time in the middle of a config write, so it will be difficult to create a test for and validate that it no longer occurs.
@granthenke One last question since I think we may have missed something with one of the exceptions we have in both `common` and `clients`, but otherwise LGTM.

Trivial patch, but it was suggested I leave it open for some discussion. Right now we're running into some internal Jenkins issues because we have changes to this branch which are still being called "0.9.0.0" and cause downstream issues in our schema-registry code. This is difficult/annoying to fix without Kafka making a clear distinction between versions and when code should be considered a SNAPSHOT (which can also cause builds to break, but at least is expected).

Another alternative would be to change this to 0.9.0.1 immediately instead of 0.9.0.1-SNAPSHOT, although personally I prefer starting to be more careful about marking code that isn't released and should not be considered stable as such.

/cc @junrao @gwenshap @ijuma
We usually self-commit the version bumps :) Anyway, LGTM.

LGTM. Do we need to update the release process wiki page to mention that the `SNAPSHOT` needs to be removed before creating the RC?

https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Release+Process

![Review all the things](http://i.imgur.com/w9JmlS8.jpg)

@gwenshap I actually filed this for the purpose of discussion since we seem to only have been using -SNAPSHOT on trunk, and I the number of patches going into 0.9.0.1 (assuming it happens) is actually substantial compared to previous release.
@ijuma: Added a quick note to that wiki. Agree we should further refine those instructions so the whole process avoids multiple versions of the code with release-style version numbers.
@ewencp looks good, thanks.

The use of reflections is not exposed to clients (and we really shouldn't expose it), so if we decide to replace it with our own class lookup code, it should be transparent.

So, I think we can replace it even after the next release.

@gwenshap Fair enough. It is at least isolated to Connect (or, once we have it, apps using Connect's embedded interface) and removing it should never cause a problem. The Guava dep does scare me a bit though -- I think we probably want to file a follow up JIRA because long term I think we will end up wanting to get rid of it.

LGTM!
@junrao, I updated the code to take into account your feedback. Tests passed locally. Please take a look when you have a chance.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
LGTM
Thanks Ewen, closing (unfortunately, GitHub only closes PRs that are merged to the default branch).
Had any thoughts on how to get rid of Guava? i.e by contributing to Reflections? forking them? Getting rid of them?

@gwenshap I was thinking by replacing it. I don't know that there's a better option in terms of existing libraries, but I feel like we're using a pretty small piece of functionality. But I also haven't tried implementing it, so maybe it's not as simple as I assume it should be :)
